newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Canberra forecasts 7 pct construction growth.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Canberra forecasts 7 pct construction growth.

text.p: The Australian government's Construction Forecasting Committee on Tuesday predicted seven percent real growth in non-residential construction in the fiscal year to June 1997, compared with 11 percent in 1995/96.
Non-residential construction would grow five percent in each of the following two years, the committee said in its Medium Term Prospects report.
Non-residential construction is divided into engineering construction, such as bridges, and non-residential building, such as supermarkets or offices.
The committee forecast five percent growth in building and eight percent growth in engineering construction in 1996/97.
These year-average forecasts compare the value of activity in one year with the value in the previous year.
"During the past year the non-residential building sector recorded significant growth in shop, hotel and other-business and entertainment categories," the committee said.
This had outweighed weakness in health and education building, it said.
"Further growth is expected in hotel, other-business, factory, entertainment and miscellaneous building.

"The rate of shop building is expected to peak in the year ahead with a probable decrease in the following year, while office building activity is expected to record an overall rise over the next three years."
The committee, drawing together private and government experts, expected mining to maintain engineering construction in 1996/97.

"A number of large privately funded infrastructure projects and continued growth in telecommunications are expected to add to significant growth for private engineering construction over the forecast period."
